Topic.Title: Obamas other quote of the day

Message.Msg: 'Bash mobs' sweep through Southern California print Comments Long Beach police brace for a possible "bash mob." July 19, 2013, 11:59 a.m. Organized black "bash mob" crime rampages of roving groups attacking innocent people and businesses have been striking cities around the United States. Law enforcement agencies in Southern California have reported few similar problems -- until now. In the last several days, there have been several reports of such group crime waves in South L.A., Hollywood, San Bernardino and Victorville. Long Beach police are bracing for another one Friday. These so-called bash mobs of "flash mob" crime waves are organized through social media and have been a problem in Chicago, Philadelphia and Washington. In April, 28 Chicago youths were arrested on suspicion of attacking pedestrians along the city's famed Magnificent Mile. Illinois Gov. Pat Quinn signed legislation in May enacting stiffer penalties for people who text or use social media to organize mob attacks. Long Beach police warned in a statement that participants could face severe penalties. "The mere participation in such an event can result in felony charges including conspiracy, and are punishable by imprisonment in the state prison," according to the statement.

Message.Title: Hate crime victim ( must make virginia's Cuccinelli pub Cuccinelli happy)
Message.Msg: Hate crime victim . "Alan Turing, the Enigma codebreaker who took his own life after being convicted of gross indecency under anti-homosexuality legislation, is to be given a posthumous pardon. The government signalled on Friday that it is prepared to support a backbench bill that would pardon Turing, who died from cyanide poisoning at the age of 41 in 1954 after he was subjected to "chemical castration". Lord Ahmad of Wimbledon, a government whip, told peers that the government would table the third reading of the Alan Turing (statutory pardon) bill at the end of October if no amendments are made. "If nobody tables an amendment to this bill, its supporters can be assured that it will have speedy passage to the House of Commons," Ahmad said. The announcement marks a change of heart by the government, which declined last year to grant pardons to the 49,000 gay men, now dead, who were convicted under the 1885 Criminal Law Amendment Act. They include Oscar Wilde." Luckily for Western civilization he was caught and persecuted for being gay AFTER his monumental contribution to the war effort

Topic.Title: There has always been the right for people to defend themselves here in Fl

Message.Msg: My two uncles used to loan money in Florida. They went to collect from a man. The one uncle went to the door while the other stayed in the car. The man came out with a pistol pointed at the one at the door. My uncle grabbed it and they fell to the floor. The gun went off And the uncle in the car thought his brother had been shot. He grabbed a .410 shotgun and ran up and shot the guy in the leg. It turned out the younger uncle had twisted the guys hand around when the gun went off and he shot himself in the side. He survived but both men stood trial. They were acquitted. This was forty years ago. I believe every state allows self defense even if fatal. I like Arizona's "Concealed Carry" law. I make use of it.

Message.Msg: "Enigma code breaker?" They recovered from a sunken U-Boat an Enigma "machine".. That's how the code was broken. The code got it's name from the machine. Interested in code? Find, if you can, "The strange case of Tyler Kent". He was a code clerk in our London Embassy at the start of WW2. He died in Kerrville, Texas a few years ago. He was held incommunicado in a British jail for most of WW2 even though having diplomatic immunity. Released after the war with no charges but would never talk about the case.

Topic.Title: Hate crime victim ( must make virginia's Cuccinelli pub Cuccinelli happy)

Message.Msg: Yes Turing was the Enigma code breaker. "Alan Mathison Turing, OBE, FRS (/ˈtjʊərɪŋ/ TEWR-ing; 23 June 1912 – 7 June 1954), was a British mathematician, logician, cryptanalyst, and computer scientist. He was highly influential in the development of computer science, giving a formalisation of the concepts of "algorithm" and "computation" with the Turing machine, which can be considered a model of a general purpose computer.[2][3][4] Turing is widely considered to be the father of computer science and artificial intelligence.[5] During World War II, Turing worked for the Government Code and Cypher School (GC&CS) at Bletchley Park, Britain's codebreaking centre. For a time he was head of Hut 8, the section responsible for German naval cryptanalysis. He devised a number of techniques for breaking German ciphers, including the method of the bombe, an electromechanical machine that could find settings for the Enigma machine."
